name: Apley’s Test
description: Determination of meniscal tear in the knee by grinding the joint manually

name: Argyll–Robertson Pupil
description: Bilaterally small, irregular, unequal pupils that react to accommodation but not to light. Seen with tertiary syphilis

name: Austin Flint Murmur
description: Late diastolic mitral murmur; associated with aortic insufficiency with a normal mitral valve

name: Babinski’s Sign
description: Extension of the large toe with stimulation of the plantar surface of the foot instead of the normal flexion; indicative of upper motor neuron disease (normal in neonates)

name: Bainbridge’s Reflex
description: Increased heart rate due to increased right atrial pressure

name: Battle’s Sign
description: Ecchymosis behind the ear associated with basilar skull fractures.

name: Beau’s Lines
description: Transverse depressions in nails due to previous systemic disease

name: Biot’s Breathing
description: Seen with brain injury; abruptly alternating apnea and equally deep breaths

name: Bergman’s Triad
description: Altered mental status, petechiae, and dyspnea associated with fat embolus syndrome

name: Bell’s Palsy
description: Lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve affecting muscles of upper and lower face. Easily distinguished from upper motor lesions, which affect predominately muscles of lower face since upper motor neurons from each side innervate muscles on both sides of the upper face

name: Beck’s Triad
description: JVD, diminished or muffled heart sounds, and decreased blood pressure associated with cardiac tamponade

name: Bisferious Pulse
description: A double-peaked pulse seen in severe chronic aortic insufficiency

name: Bitot’s Spots
description: Small scleral white patches suggesting vitamin A deficiency

name: Blumberg’ Sign
description: Pain felt in the abdomen when steady constant pressure is quickly released. Seen with peritonitis

name: Blumer’s Shelf
description: Hardness palpable on rectal examination due to metastatic cancer of the rectouterine (pouch of Douglas) or rectovesical pouch
disease: Metastatic cancer of Rectovesical pouch or Rectouterine pouch

name: Bouchard’s Nodes
description: Hard, nontender, painless nodules in the dorsolateral aspects of the proximal interphalangeal joints associated with osteoarthritis. Results from hypertrophy of the bone

name: Branham’s Sign
description: With large AV fistulas, abrupt slowing of the heart rate with compression of the feeding artery

name: Brudzinski’s Sign
description: Flexion of the neck causing flexion of the hips in meningitis

name: Chadwick’s Sign
description: Bluish color of cervix and vagina, seen with pregnancy

name: Chandelier’s Sign
description: Extreme pain elicited with movement of the cervix during bimanual pelvic examination. Indicates PID

name: Charcot’s Triad
description: Right upper quadrant pain, fever (chills), and jaundice associated with cholangitis

name: Cheyne–Stokes Respiration
description: Repeating cycle of a gradual increase in depth of breathing followed by a gradual decrease to apnea; seen with CNS disorders, uremia, some normal sleep patterns

name: Chvostek’s Sign
description: Tapping over the facial nerve causes facial spasm in hypocalcemia(tetany). May be normal finding in some patients

name: Corrigan’s Pulse
description: A palpable hard pulse immediately followed by sudden collapse, seen in aortic regurgitation

name: Cullen’s Sign
description: Ecchymosis around the umbilicus associated with severe intraperitoneal bleeding. Seen with ruptured ectopic pregnancy and hemorrhagic pancreatitis

name: Cushing’s Triad
description: Hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration associated with increased intracranial pressure

name: Darier’s Sign
description: Stroking of the skin causes erythema and edema in mastocytosis

name: Doll’s Eyes
description: Conjugated movement of eyes in one direction as head is briskly turned in the other direction in comatose patients. Tests oculocephalic reflex indicating intact brain stem

name: Drawer Sign
description: Forward (or backward) movement of the tibia with pressure, indicating laxity or a tear in the anterior (or posterior) cruciate ligament

name: Dupuytren’s Contracture
description: Proliferation of fibrosis tissue of the palmar fascia resulting in contracture of the fourth and/or fifth digits, which is often bilateral. May be hereditary or seen in patients with chronic alcoholic liver disease or seizures

name: Duroziez’s Sign
description: Found in aortic regurgitation a“to and fro” murmur when stethoscope is pressed over the femoral artery

name: Electrical Alternans
description: Beat to beat variation in the electrical axis, seen in large pericardial effusions, suggests impending hemodynamic compromise

name: Ewart’s Sign
description: Dullness to percussion, increased fremitus and bronchial breathing beneath the angle of the left scapula found with pericardial effusion

name: Fong Lesion/Syndrome
description: Autosomal-dominant anomalies of the nails and patella associated with renal abnormalities

name: Frank’s Sign
description: Fissure of the ear lobe; may be associated with CAD, diabetes, and hypertension

name: Gibbus deformity
description: Angular convexity of the spine due to vertebral collapse; associated with osteoporosis or metastasis

name: Gregg’s Triad
description: Cataracts, heart defects, and deafness with congenital rubella

name: Grey Turner’s Sign
description: Ecchymosis in the flank associated with retroperitoneal hemorrhage

name: Grocco’s Sign
description: Triangular area of paravertebral dullness, opposite side of a pleural effusion

name: Heberden’s Nodes
description: Hard, nontender, painless nodules on the dorsolateral aspects of the distal interphalangeal joints associated with osteoarthritis. Results from hypertrophy of the bone

name: Hegar’s Sign
description: Softening of the distal uterus. Reliable early sign of pregnancy

name: Hellenhorst’s Plaque:
description: A cholesterol plaque on retina seen on funduscopic examination associated with amaurosis fugax

name: Hill’s Sign
description: Femoral artery pressure 20 mm Hg greater than brachial pressure seen in severe aortic regurgitation

name: Hoffmann’s Sign/Reflex
description: Flicking of the volar surface of the distal phalanx causing fingers to flex; associated with pyramidal tract disease

name: Homans’ Sign
description: Calf pain with forcible dorsiflexion of the foot, associated with venous thrombosis

name: Horner’s Syndrome
description: Unilateral miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis (absence of sweating). From destruction of ipsilateral superior cervical ganglion often from lung carcinoma, especially squamous cell carcinoma

name: Janeway’s Lesions
description: Erythematous or hemorrhagic lesion seen on the palm or sole with subacute bacterial endocarditis

name: Joffroy’s Reflex
description: Inability to wrinkle the forehead when patient asked to bend head and look up, seen in hyperthyroidism

name: Kayser–Fleischer Ring
description: Brown pigment lesion due to copper deposition seen in Wilson’s disease

name: Kehr’s Sign
description: Left shoulder and left upper quadrant pain associated with splenic rupture

name: Kernig’s Sign
description: When the thigh is flexed at a right angle, complete extension of the leg is not possible because of inflammation of the meninges; seen with meningitis

name: Koplik’s Spots
description: White papules on buccal mucosa opposite molars seen in measles

name: Korotkoff’s Sounds
description: Low-pitched sounds resulting from vibration of the artery, detected when obtaining a blood pressure using the bell of the stethoscope. The last Korotkoff sound may be a more accurate estimate of the true diastolic blood pressure than the diastolic blood pressure obtained using the diaphragm.

name: Kussmaul’s Respiration
description: Deep, rapid respiratory pattern seen in coma or DKA

name: Kussmaul’s Sign
description: Paradoxical rise in the jugular venous pressure on inspiration in constrictive pericarditis or COPD

name: Kyphosis
description: Excessive rounding of the thoracic spinal convexity, associated with aging, especially in women

name: Straight-Leg-Raising Sign
description: The patient is extended in the supine position and raises the leg gently. Pain in the distribution of nerve root suggests sciatica.

name: Levine’s Sign
description: Clenched fist over the chest while describing chest pain; associated with angina and AMI

name: Lhermitte’s Sign
description: In MS, neck flexion results in a shock sensation

name: List
description: Lateral tilt of the spine, frequently associated with herniated disk and muscle spasm

name: Lordosis
description: Accentuated normal concavity of the lumbar spine, normal in pregnancy

name: Louvel’s Sign
description: Coughing or sneezing causes pain in the leg with DVT

name: Marcus–Gunn Pupil
description: Dilation of pupils with swinging flashlight test. Results from unilateral optic nerve disease. Normal pupillary response is elicited when light is directed from the normal eye and a subnormal response when light is quickly directed from the normal eye into the abnormal eye. When light is directed into the abnormal eye, both pupils dilate rather than maintain the previous degree of miosis.

name: McBurney’s Point/Sign
description: Point located one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus on the right; tenderness at the site is associated with acute appendicitis.

name: McMurray’s Test
description: External rotation of the foot produces a palpable or audible click on the joint line, suggesting medial meniscal injuries

name: Möbius’ Sign
description: Weakness of convergence seen in thyrotoxicosis

name: Moro’s Reflex (Startle Reflex)
description: Abduction of hips and arms with extension of arms when infant’s head and upper body is suddenly dropped several inches while being held. Normal reflex in early infancy

name: Murphy’s Sign
description: Severe pain and inspiratory arrest with palpation of the right upper quadrant during deep inspiration; associated with cholecystitis

name: Musset’s(de Musset’s Sign)
description: Abduction of hips and arms with extension of arms when infant’s head and upper body is suddenly dropped several inches while being held. Normal reflex in early infancy

name: Obturator Sign
description: Flexion and internal rotation of the thigh elicits hypogastric pain in cases of inflammation of the obturator internus; positive with pelvic abscess and appendicitis

name: Ortolani’s Test/Sign
description: Hip click that suggests congenital hip dislocation. With the infant supine, point the legs toward you and flex the legs to 90 degrees at the hips and knees

name: Pancoast’s Syndrome
description: Carcinoma involving apex of lung, resulting in arm and or shoulder pain from involvement of brachial plexus and Horner’s syndrome from involvement of the superior cervical ganglion

name: Pastia’s Lines
description: Linear striations of confluent petechiae in axillary folds are antecubital fossa seen in scarlet fever

name: Phalen’s Test
description: Prolonged maximum flexion of wrists while opposing dorsum of each hand against each other. A positive test results in pain and tingling in the distribution of the median nerve, indicating carpal tunnel syndrome

name: Psoas Sign
description: Flexion against resistance or extension of the right hip, producing pain; seen with inflammation of the psoas muscle; positive with appendicitis.

name: Pulsus Alternans
description: Fluctuation of pulse pressure with every other beat. Seen in aortic stenosis and CHF

name: Queckenstedt’s Test
description: Tests patency of the subarachnoid space; compression of the internal jugular vein during lumbar puncture; should normally immediately raise CSF pressure

name: Quincke’s Sign
description: Alternating blushing and blanching of the fingernail bed following light compression; seen in chronic aortic regurgitation

name: Radovici’s Sign
description: A frontal release sign, scratching palm causes chin contractions

name: Raynaud’s phenomenon
description: Pain and tingling in fingers after exposure to cold with characteristic color changes of white to blue and then often red. May be seen with scleroderma, and SLE

name: Romberg’s Test
description: Used to test position sense or cerebellar function. The patient stands with heels and toes together. Arms may be outstretched with palms facing upward or down or arms can be at the patient’s side. The patient may be lightly tapped by the examiner with the eyes open and then closed. A positive test is a loss of balance. A loss of balance with the eyes open indicates cerebellar dysfunction. Normal balance with eyes open and loss of balance with eyes closed indicates loss of position sense.

name: Roth’s Spots
description: Oval retinal hemorrhages with a pale central area occurring in patients with bacterial endocarditis

name: Rovsing’s Sign
description: Pain in the right lower quadrant with deep palpation of the left lower quadrant. Seen in acute appendicitis

name: Schmorl’s Node
description: Degeneration of the intervertebral disk resulting in herniation into the adjacent vertebral body

name: Scoliosis
description: Lateral curvature of the spine

name: Sentinel Loop
description: A single dilated loop of small or large bowel, usually occurs localized inflammation such as pancreatitis

name: Sister Mary Joseph’s Nodule
description: Metastatic cancer to umbilical lymph node

name: Stellwag’s Sign
description: Stellwag's sign is a sign of infrequent or incomplete blinking associated with exophthalmos or Graves orbitopathy. It is accompanied by Dalrymple's sign, which is a retraction of the upper eyelids resulting in an apparent widening of the palpebral opening

name: Tinel’s Sign
description: Radiation of an electric shock sensation in the distal distribution of the median nerve elicited by percussion of the flexor surface of the wrist when fully extended. Seen in carpal tunnel syndrome

name: Traube’s Sign
description: Booming or pistol shot sounds heard over the femoral arteries in chronic aortic insufficiency

name: Trendelenburg’s Test
description: Observe patient from behind while patient shifts weight from one leg to the other; a pelvis tilt to opposite side suggests hip disease and weakness of the gluteus medius muscle. If normal, pelvis will not tilt

name: Trousseau’s Sign
description: Carpal spasm produced by inflating a blood pressure cuff above the systolic pressure for 2–3 min, indicates hypocalcemia; also migratory thrombophlebitis associated with cancer

name: Virchow’s Node
description: A palpable, left supraclavicular lymph node; often first sign of a GI neoplasm, such as pancreatic or gastric carcinoma

name: von Graefe’s Sign
description: Lid lag associated with thyrotoxicosis

name: Weber–Rinne Test
description: For the Weber test a 512 or 1024-Hz tuning fork is placed on the middle of the skull to determine if the sound lateralizes. For the Rinne test, the tuning fork is held against the mastoid process (BC) with the opposite ear covered. The patient  ndicates when the sound is gone. The tuning  ork is then held next to the ear and the patient indicates whether the sound is present and when the sound (AC) disappears. Normally AC is better than BC. With sensorineural hearing loss, the Weber test lateralizes to the less affected ear and AC > BC; with conduction hearing loss, the Weber test lateralizes to the more affected ear and BC > AC

name: Whipple’s Triad
description: Hypoglycemia, CNS, and vasomotor symptoms (ie, diaphoresis, syncope); relief of symptoms with glucose; associated with insulinoma
